    <item>
      <title>Senior Trump adviser says Russian election meddling 'beyond dispute'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/17/donald-trump-hr-mcmaster-russia-election-meddling-investigation</link>
      <description><p>HR McMaster calls evidence incontrovertible in wake of latest US indictments against more than a dozen Russians </p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/robert-mueller-russians-charged-election">Mueller charges 13 Russians with interfering in US election to help Trump</a></li></ul><p>Donald Trump’s national security adviser, HR McMaster, said on Saturday that Russian meddling in the 2016 election is “incontrovertible” and “beyond dispute” in the wake of new US indictments.</p><p>McMaster spoke after Robert Mueller, the special counsel in the Russia investigation, revealed new details about Moscow’s sophisticated cyber-meddling campaign on Friday.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/17/donald-trump-hr-mcmaster-russia-election-meddling-investigation">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Iran plane crash in south of country 'kills all 65 onboard'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/iran-plane-crashes-aseman-airlines-yasuj</link>
      <description><p>Aseman Airlines plane crashed en route from Tehran to Yasuj in severe weather conditions, according to state media reports</p><p>All passengers and crew onboard an Iranian commercial flight died after the plane crashed amid severe weather conditions in a mountainous region in the south of the country, state television reported on Sunday. </p><p>Aseman Airlines flight 3705, en route from Tehran to the southern city of Yasuj, the capital of the impoverished province of Kohgiluyeh and Boyer-Ahmad, went off radar 50 minutes into its journey, not far from its destination.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/iran-plane-crashes-aseman-airlines-yasuj">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ramaphosa set to purge cabinet of Zuma cronies in war on corruption</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/17/cyril-ramaphosa-purge-zuma-cronies-south-africa-corruption</link>
      <description>New president calls on South Africa to unite as police step up hunt for  former leader’s son and missing Gupta brother<p>Cyril Ramaphosa, the new president of South Africa, is expected to move within days to purge his cabinet of ministers tainted by allegations of corruption, and to intensify efforts to bring to trial high-profile businessmen alleged to have made millions under his predecessor, Jacob Zuma.</p><p>Ramaphosa, 65, hailed a “new dawn” in South Africa in his first major speech on Friday and promised to fight to “turn the tide of corruption in our public institutions”. His speech, with its call to all South Africans to unite to set the country on a new path, prompted an outpouring of enthusiastic patriotism in the media.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/17/cyril-ramaphosa-purge-zuma-cronies-south-africa-corruption">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Iceland law to outlaw male circumcision sparks row over religious freedom</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/18/iceland-ban-male-circumcision-first-european-country</link>
      <description><p>Jewish and Muslim leaders condemn first European country to propose ban</p><p>Iceland is poised to become the first European country to outlaw <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/aug/28/circumcision-the-cruellest-cut" title="">male circumcision</a> amid signs that the ritual common to both Judaism and Islam may be a new battleground over religious freedom.</p><p>A bill currently before the Icelandic parliament proposes a penalty of up to six years in prison for anyone <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/the-lay-scientist/2011/dec/06/1" title="">carrying out a circumcision other than for medical reasons</a>. Critics say the move, which has sparked alarm among religious leaders across Europe, would make life for Jews and Muslims in Iceland unsustainable.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/18/iceland-ban-male-circumcision-first-european-country">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Italy used to be a tolerant country, but now racism is rising</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/italy-used-to-be-a-tolerant-country-but-now-racism-is-rising</link>
      <description>The upcoming election has unleashed a tide of anti-migrant action, whose roots can be traced to the financial crisis and the country’s weakened leftwing<p>Pape Diaw, originally from Senegal, arrived in Florence to study engineering in the late 1970s. Part of a group of 15 African students, he inspired curiosity among his Italian counterparts and the wider community, but never encountered racism. “I remember walking along the street and people would ask to have a photo taken,” he said.</p><p>“We were seen as a novelty, but never insulted. When we went to process our residency permits, the police officers would give us coffee.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/italy-used-to-be-a-tolerant-country-but-now-racism-is-rising">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Michelle Obama portrait puts black Baltimore artist in the spotlight</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/18/michelle-obama-portrait-amy-sherald-baltimore-conversation</link>
      <description>The commission of a lifetime for Amy Sherald has kickstarted a conversation about art, politics and culture<p>She is a Baltimore-based artist who only paints African-American subjects and always uses a muted palette. But last week, Amy Sherald became the art world’s latest sensation as her <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2018/feb/12/barack-obama-michelle-obama-national-portrait-gallery" title="">portrait of former first lady Michelle Obama</a> was unveiled in Washington.</p><p>Sherald, 44, almost didn’t get to paint Obama. She put away her brushes for three years to care for her family in Georgia. Then, in 2012, she collapsed and underwent a heart transplant that meant she needed another year to recuperate.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/18/michelle-obama-portrait-amy-sherald-baltimore-conversation">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Israeli jets and tanks strike Gaza after bomb injures soldiers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/17/four-israeli-soldiers-injured-two-seriously-in-border-blast</link>
      <description><p>Israel’s military says it targeted Hamas positions after IED on border injured four troops</p><p>Israel has used jets and tanks to strike the Gaza Strip in response to the explosion of an improvised explosive device that wounded four of its soldiers, marking one of the most severe escalations of violence since the 2014 war. </p><p>Gaza’s Hamas-run government said two Palestinian 17-year-olds were killed by Israeli tank fire during Saturday night’s attacks, sending photos to journalists of what appeared to be two bodies on stretchers.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/17/four-israeli-soldiers-injured-two-seriously-in-border-blast">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Pakistan court sentences man to death for rape and murder of girl, 7</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/17/zainab-ansari-pakistan-sentences-man-to-death-for-and-of-girl-7</link>
      <description><p>Imran Ali, 24, convicted over death of Zainab Ansari, has also been linked to death of seven other girls</p><p>A Pakistani anti-terrorism court has sentenced a suspected serial killer to death for the rape and murder of a seven-year-old girl, a prosecutor said. </p><p>The girl’s murder ignited nationwide protests over allegations of government inaction, and a media campaign led to his arrest after years of him being on the loose. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/17/zainab-ansari-pakistan-sentences-man-to-death-for-and-of-girl-7">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Pope Francis wowed the world but, five years on, is in troubled waters</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/pope-francis-attitude-abuse-scandal-catholic-church-critics</link>
      <description>He entered office on a wave of energy but, as discontent grows over his attitude to abuse scandals, Francis faces opposition on all sides<p>Chatham House is one of the most important foreign affairs thinktanks in the UK. But on Wednesday its focus will not be a president, or an organisation like the World Bank, or the future of the EU after Brexit, but a religious leader: Pope Francis. And it will be the third time in recent weeks that Britain has turned its attention to the pope.</p><p>Two weeks ago, the Foreign Office-sponsored thinktank Wilton Park took delegates to the Vatican to meet the pope and discuss violent religious extremism, while last week the Metropolitan police commissioner, Cressida Dick, was in Rome to talk with Francis about modern slavery.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/pope-francis-attitude-abuse-scandal-catholic-church-critics">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/pope-francis">Pope Francis</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/italy">Italy</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/europe-news">Europe</category>

    <item>
      <title>Amid the chaos of Syria, will Israel and Iran launch an all-out war?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/amid-chaos-syria-will-israel-iran-launch-all-out-war</link>
      <description>Neither country will benefit from a new Middle East conflict, but unless they cease military clashes, such as those inside Syria last weekend, hopes of peace remain fragile<p>Tensions between Israel and Iran have hit a new high following last weekend’s unprecedented <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/10/israeli-fighter-jet-shot-down-by-syrian-fire-says-military" title="">military clashes inside Syria</a>. The fighting has intensified fears that the Middle East is heading for all-out war. But such alarming predictions assume both protagonists standing toe-to-toe, actuallywant to fight. Is this reallytrue?</p><p>Iran is portrayed as a wanton aggressor, especially by the Trump administration and the Saudis. It has steadily expanded its military presence in Syria since supporting Bashar al-Assad after 2011, deploying Afghan and Pakistani Shia militias, Lebanese Hezbollah fighters and its own Revolutionary Guards.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/amid-chaos-syria-will-israel-iran-launch-all-out-war">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Non-invasive imaging reveals landscape painting beneath Pablo Picasso’s The Crouching Beggar but who created it remains a mystery</p><p>Wrapped in a mustard coloured blanket with a white scarf and her head on one side, Pablo Picasso’s <em>La Misereuse Accroupie</em> (The Crouching Beggar) is a study of forlorn resignation.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/17/harvey-weinstein-canada-lawsuit-barbara-schneeweiss</link>
      <description><p>Judge dismisses former assistant’s challenge to lawsuit, which claims she knew of Weinstein’s predation and helped facilitate attacks</p><p>A Canadian judge has rejected a bid to dismiss an anonymous actor’s $4m sexual assault lawsuit against Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein, his former assistant and two entertainment companies. </p><p>In a ruling released on Friday, the Toronto judge Patrick Monohan dismissed a challenge to the actor’s lawsuit filed by Weinstein’s former assistant Barbara Schneeweiss which argued that the<strong> </strong>allegations concerning her had expired under Ontario statute of limitations laws.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/17/harvey-weinstein-canada-lawsuit-barbara-schneeweiss">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Dongguan in the spotlight: hi-tech comeback for 'factory of the world'?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2018/feb/16/dongguan-spotlight-china-factory-world-hi-tech</link>
      <description><p>After an economic slump lasting years, Dongguan – the home of ‘Made in China’ – is reinventing itself as a robotics base</p><p>This month Dongguan, in the heart of the Pearl River Delta economic zone of south China, is transformed from a city of migrants into a city of ghosts.</p><p>The Chinese New Year holiday marks the start of the biggest annual human migration on the planet. During the Spring Festival travel rush – or <em tabindex="-1">Chunyun</em> in Mandarin – which runs from 1 February to 12 March 2018, it’s estimated that Chinese returning to their home towns for family reunions will make 2.98 billion trips. According to China’s <a draggable="true" href="http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-01/31/c_136939276.htm">National Development and Reform Commission</a>, in total, 2.48 billion road trips, 390 million rail trips, 65 million air trips and 46 million boat trips are expected to be made over the 40-day period. Nowhere is this large-scale migration likely to be more evident than in Dongguan, an industrial city in central Guangdong province.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2018/feb/16/dongguan-spotlight-china-factory-world-hi-tech">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The story of Mr Sudhir: how to survive in Delhi's 'grey market'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2018/feb/15/story-mr-sudhir-survive-delhis-grey-market-nehru-place-india</link>
      <description><p>When sociologist Richard Sennett was fleeced by an iPhone dealer in Delhi, the pair struck up a friendship that opened a window into the informality of modern cities</p><p>In the south-east of Delhi, a vast T-shaped market has arisen on top of an underground parking garage. <br></p><p>Nehru Place came into being because in the 1970s Delhi did not have enough commercial real estate to house its burgeoning small businesses. Original plans show the plaza above the parking garage as empty, and lined with low, four-storey buildings meant for offices rather than shops. Today, there remain traces of that intention. The boxy buildings lining the sides of Nehru Place form a downmarket version of Silicon Valley. Here, tech startups occupy cramped rooms next to computer repair shops and cut-rate travel agents. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2018/feb/15/story-mr-sudhir-survive-delhis-grey-market-nehru-place-india">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>For four years, photographer Jonathan Rentschler spent most days or nights at Love Park in Philadelphia, documenting the skateboarding community that congregated there before its closure for renovation in 2016<br></p><ul><li><a href="https://paradigmpublishing.co/products/love">LOVE</a> by Jonathan Rentschler is published by Paradigm Publishing<br></li></ul> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/cities/gallery/2018/feb/14/love-park-photos-book-skate-philidelphia-jonathan-rentschler">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/nigeria-releases-475-boko-haram-suspects-for-rehabilitation</link>
      <description><p>Authorities said some suspected of links with militants had been held without trial since 2010<br></p><p>A Nigerian court has released 475 people allegedly affiliated with Boko Haram for rehabilitation, the justice ministry said, as the country’s biggest legal investigation of the militant Islamist insurgency continued.</p><p> The first person convicted for the kidnapping in 2014 of Chibok schoolgirls, sentenced to 15 years’ imprisonment last week, was also handed an additional 15-year sentence, to run back-to-back, the ministry said in a statement.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/nigeria-releases-475-boko-haram-suspects-for-rehabilitation">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/18/donald-trump-fbi-russia-inquiry-florida-shooting</link>
      <description><p>The president’s attempt to use the shooting to make a political point about the Russia inquiries drew swift criticism</p><p>Donald Trump has criticized the FBI for missing the “many signals” about the Florida school shooter, saying the agency was spending “too much time” trying to prove Russian collusion with the Trump campaign. <br></p><p>The US president’s attempt to use the shooting to make a political point about the FBI’s Russia inquiries into the Trump campaign drew swift criticism, including from John Kasich, the Republican governor of Ohio, who told CNN it was an “absurd statement”. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/18/donald-trump-fbi-russia-inquiry-florida-shooting">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Canada indigenous leaders divided over Trudeau's pledge to put them first</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/canada-indigenous-first-nations-justin-trudeau-pledge-reaction</link>
      <description><p>While some welcomed the promise to recognize ‘the rights of First Nations’, others saw it as a way to silence negative press </p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/14/canada-justin-trudeau-indigenous-groups">Justin Trudeau pledges full legal framework for indigenous Canadians</a><br></li></ul><p>When the Canadian prime minister, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/justin-trudeau" style="background-color: white;">Justin Trudeau</a>, came to power in 2015, he pledged to <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/dec/15/justin-trudeau-pledges-reconciliation-canada-aboriginal-abuse" style="background-color: white;">mend the broken relationship with indigenous peoples</a> across the country, recognizing that “the rights of First Nations in Canada are not an inconvenience but rather a sacred obligation”.<br></p><p>In speech to the House of Commons this week, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/14/canada-justin-trudeau-indigenous-groups">he admitted the promise has gone unfulfilled</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/canada-indigenous-first-nations-justin-trudeau-pledge-reaction">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/more-nauru-refugees-depart-for-us-as-attack-on-manus-provokes-panic</link>
      <description><ul><li>Iranians excluded from group of 35 refugees </li><li>Men on Manus Island allege PNG soldiers attacked them<br></li></ul><p>Another 35 refugees are leaving Nauru for the United States on Sunday, the third group to depart Australia’s offshore immigration centres this week.<br><br>Almost all are single Afghan, Pakistani or Rohingya men, along with one Sri Lankan family and one Bangladeshi refugee, said Ian Rintoul of the the Refugee Action Coalition.</p><p>The makeup further confirms fears that Iranians, who make up the largest national group on Nauru, have so far been excluded from the US intake. Iran was proscribed by <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trumps-travel-ban">Donald Trump’s “travel ban”</a>. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/more-nauru-refugees-depart-for-us-as-attack-on-manus-provokes-panic">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mexico’s Zapatista rebels, 24 years on and defiant in mountain strongholds</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/17/mexico-zapatistas-rebels-24-years-mountain-strongholds</link>
      <description>The peasant rebels took up arms in 1994, and now number 300,000 in centres with their own doctors, teachers and currency, but rarely answer questions – until now<p>Diners in the Tierradentro cafe in the southern Mexican town of San Cristóbal de las Casas can choose between a variety of omelettes. The “Liberty” has the most ingredients, the “Democracy” looks the best, but the “Justice” costs the most – possibly because it comes with cheese.</p><p>The restaurant is one of many celebrating, or cashing in on, the Zapatistas, the indigenous peasant rights movement from dirt-poor Chiapas state, which took up arms and occupied San Cristóbal on 1 January 1994, the day Mexico signed up to Nafta, the North American free trade agreement.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/17/mexico-zapatistas-rebels-24-years-mountain-strongholds">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/global-development">Global development</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/indigenous-peoples">Indigenous peoples</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/mexico">Mexico</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/americas">Americas</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/world">World news</category>
      <pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 20:30:24 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/17/mexico-zapatistas-rebels-24-years-mountain-strongholds</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/886aa80013a463baf4cbf00f019e4d863067ab58/0_122_4866_2920/master/4866.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=14fb3e2b272ccacdc992b5b7086debe2">

      <title>‘It was heartbreaking’: the bleak truth behind Bafta-chasing migrant drama</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/17/heartbreaking-bleak-truth-bafta-chasing-migrant-drama-aamir-vika-evdokimenko</link>
      <description><p>Stark realities underpin Aamir, Vika Evdokimenko’s ostensibly fictional tale of a young migrant forced to fend for himself</p><p>Aamir is just 13. Like many teenagers, his coming of age is marked by a wispy moustache above his upper lip, a vulnerability in his hunched shoulders, a voice not yet broken.</p><p>But after soldiers break into his family home in Mosul and shoot and kill his father, Aamir must become a man. His mother sends him away with a few wads of cash and his father’s watch as insurance, hoping to give him a better life – one he might actually survive. But as the boy tries to find his feet all alone in a foreign world, will he end up losing his mind in the process?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/17/heartbreaking-bleak-truth-bafta-chasing-migrant-drama-aamir-vika-evdokimenko">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Oxfam scandal does not justify demonising the entire aid sector | Megan Nobert</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/17/oxfam-scandal-does-not-justify-demonising-entire-aid-sector</link>
      <description><p>Aid agencies are learning how to deal with sexual misconduct more sensitively – let’s give them space to do so</p><p>The #MeToo movement has been sparking change across the world. Now the humanitarian community has become <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/12/metoo-strikes-aid-sector-as-sexual-exploitation-allegations-proliferate">the latest sector</a> forced to recognise it has a serious problem that has been neglected for too long.<br></p><p>The <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/10/oxfam-faces-allegations-staff-paid-prostitutes-in-chad">scandal</a> has highlighted <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/11/oxfam-staff-raise-concerns-over-charity-vetting-processes-haiti-abuse">sexual abuse committed by Oxfam staff</a> in Haiti in 2011. Employees who paid for sex were allowed to resign and, while <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/13/aid-worker-haiti-quake-debauchery-shocking">the incident</a> could have been handled better, it sparked a change in the organisation. They introduced stronger policies and processes, strengthened their investigative department. Oxfam began taking a zero-tolerance policy in actions, not just words. Were an accusation made now, it would be <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/16/oxfam-international-boss-vows-to-root-out-wrongdoing-at-charity">handled differently</a>. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/17/oxfam-scandal-does-not-justify-demonising-entire-aid-sector">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/16/oxfam-chief-accuses-critics-of-gunning-for-charity-over-haiti-sex-scandal-claims</link>
      <description><p>Mark Goldring admits organisation’s failings but says ‘scale and intensity’ of criticism is disproportionate</p><p>•<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/16/oxfam-boss-mark-goldring-anything-we-say-is-being-manipulated-weve-been-savaged">Oxfam CEO: ‘Anything we say is manipulated. We’ve been savaged’</a></p><p>The chief executive of Oxfam has hit back at the storm of criticism surrounding the charity’s sex exploitation scandal in Haiti, claiming attacks on the organisation are “out of proportion to the level of culpability”.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/16/oxfam-boss-mark-goldring-anything-we-say-is-being-manipulated-weve-been-savaged">In an interview with the Guardian</a>, Mark Goldring repeated his apology for Oxfam’s failings and acknowledged that major reforms were needed. But warning that the controversy has already affected vital donations, he accused critics of “gunning” for the charity and said some were motivated in part by an anti-aid agenda.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/16/oxfam-chief-accuses-critics-of-gunning-for-charity-over-haiti-sex-scandal-claims">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/16/one-in-10-senior-politicians-in-brazil-funded-by-companies-linked-to-slavery</link>
      <description><p>Investigation finds President Michel Temer among 51 politicians who received donations from firms accused of labour abuses</p><p>More than one in 10 of Brazil’s high-ranking politicians, among them President Michel Temer, received campaign donations from companies linked to modern-day slavery, an investigation has found.</p><p>Party leaders, state secretaries and five of ex-president Dilma Rousseff’s governors are among the elected parliamentarians who received R$3.5m (£760,000) during the last general election, according to <a draggable="true" href="http://reporterbrasil.org.br/2018/01/empresas-flagradas-com-trabalho-escravo-financiaram-10-dos-deputados-federais/">the NGO Repórter Brasil</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/feb/16/one-in-10-senior-politicians-in-brazil-funded-by-companies-linked-to-slavery">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Putin’s chef, a troll farm and Russia's plot to hijack US democracy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/17/putins-chef-a-troll-farm-and-russias-plot-to-hijack-us-democracy</link>
      <description><p>Robert Mueller has revealed audacious meddling in the 2016 election. Can he link it to Trump?</p><p>The plot against America began in 2014. Thousands of miles away, in a drab office building in St Petersburg, Russia, a fake newsroom was under construction with its own graphics, data analysis, search engine optimisation, IT and finance departments. Its mission: ”information warfare against the United States of America”.</p><p>What followed, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/robert-mueller-russians-charged-election">according to an indictment</a> brought by the US special counsel, Robert Mueller, on Friday, was a stunningly successful attack on the most powerful democracy in the world. It involved stolen identities, fake social media accounts, rallies organised from afar, US citizens duped into doing Moscow’s bidding, and two Russians going undercover in a ruse reminiscent of <em>The Americans</em>, a TV drama about KGB spies in suburban Washington during the cold war.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/17/putins-chef-a-troll-farm-and-russias-plot-to-hijack-us-democracy">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>After Florida, I see the NRA as nothing less than a terrorist organization</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/17/the-week-in-patriarchy-florida-school-shooting-nra</link>
      <description><p>What else would you call a group that ensures I need to have a conversation with my daughter about how to survive a school shooting? </p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/info/2017/jan/19/this-week-in-the-patriarchy-jessica-valenti-email">Get this newsletter via email – sign up</a><br></li></ul><p>I try so hard not to let tragedies like the one that happened <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/florida-school-shooting">at a Florida high school this week</a> feel like just another shooting. This happens so often, it’s easy to fall into frozen despair. If child after child is killed, and still our politicians do nothing – how can we expect anything to change?</p><p>The truth is that we have to stop voting for Republicans; we have to stop voting for people who take money from the NRA. At this point, I consider them nothing less than a terrorist organization – what else would you call a group that ensures I have to have a conversation with my seven-year-old about playing dead should she be unable to run away from a shooter. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/17/the-week-in-patriarchy-florida-school-shooting-nra">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Special counsel buries Trump’s obfuscations over Russian meddling, but has not yet produced compelling evidence of collusion </p><p>What Robert Mueller delivered in Friday’s indictment were the first charges for interfering in the 2016 presidential election.       <description><p>Hundreds gathered on Thursday for a prayer vigil at Parkridge church, in Parkland, Florida, after a <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/15/florida-shooting-suspect-charged-questions-nikolas-cruz">school shooting in which 17 people were killed</a>. Suspect Nikolas Cruz, 19, was arrested more than an hour after shooting began at Marjory Stoneman Douglas high school.       <title>Judge orders Florida shooting suspect to be held in jail without bond – video</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/video/2018/feb/15/judge-orders-florida-shooting-suspect-to-be-held-in-jail-without-bond-video</link>
      <description><p>Nikolas Cruz, 19, has appeared in court charged with murder of 17 people and will be held in jail without bond, a Broward County judge has ordered.&nbsp; The ex-student walked into the Marjory Stoneman Douglas high school in Parkland on 14 February and opened fire on students and teachers, Broward County sheriff Scott Israel said. Police believe he acted alone</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/video/2018/feb/15/judge-orders-florida-shooting-suspect-to-be-held-in-jail-without-bond-video">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>South African MPs celebrate as Cyril Ramaphosa is sworn in - video</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2018/feb/15/south-african-mps-celebrate-as-cyril-ramaphosa-is-sworn-in-video</link>
      <description><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/cyril-ramaphosa">Cyril Ramaphosa</a>&nbsp;has taken over as president of South Africa and, in a thinly veiled reference to accusations levelled against his predecessor Jacob Zuma, vowed to fight corruption. Ramaphosa was sworn in less than 16 hours after <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/14/jacob-zuma-resigns-south-africa-president">Zuma resigned</a>, having defiantly refused to leave office for days. Wearing a dark suit and red tie, Ramaphosa, 65, sat quietly while lawmakers from the ruling African National Congress stood, clapped and sang in celebration. He was appointed unopposed</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/15/cyril-ramaphosa-to-be-elected-president-of-south-africa-jacob-zuma">Ramaphosa vows anti-corruption drive as he takes over in South Africa</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2018/feb/15/south-african-mps-celebrate-as-cyril-ramaphosa-is-sworn-in-video">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Trump on Florida shooting: 'We hurt for the entire community' – video</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/video/2018/feb/15/florida-school-shooting-hurt-community-donald-trump-video</link>
      <description><p>The US president has called for 'healing and peace' a day after a 19-year-old man was accused of killing at least 17 people at a Florida high school, saying his administration will work to improve school safety and address mental illness problems.
